@Julius89812447 Sorry don't really understand. Have followed you if you want to explain to me by DM (longer form).
@crookedhubert yes. I agree. I hope they do. But I'm also annoyed they're so self absorbed most other times to notice.
@crookedhubert Sorry. I don't understand your point. It might be because it's too nuanced for Twitter.
@crookedhubert no they don't. Uber drivers don't use uber.
@crookedhubert yes, it's about time people realised that using an Uber is no different to buying sweatshop clothes.
@dvdbllrd We need to cultivate MORE SMEs, not more major corporate or government monopolies. (IMHO)
@dvdbllrd This would keep the system honest and competitive. Especially if the master app required competition based on "all in" cost
@dvdbllrd If the issue is "friction" no reason why small local companies couldn't be part of master app that lets ppl hop from one to other
@dvdbllrd the issue with Uber is that it's an unethically constructed monopoly. What's wrong with lots of competing local companies?
@dvdbllrd personally I don't think it should be socialised. It should be forced to operate at a profit!
@Alheri @GeorgeLakoff was it not linked to these VWP changes? https://t.co/XsMfKRP6Ti
@dpinsen i didn't take offence. It's just sometimes people's expectations are a little high.
@dpinsen this is the sort of faux opportunistic self promotional compassion I have trouble processing.
@dpinsen thanks for scoring my tweets. Feel free to unfollow.
@dpinsen because last i checked tech companies were doing their best to disrupt all low skilled jobs & make it impossible to earn a living
@dpinsen I feel the same way about the faux opportunistic compassion coming from tech companies.
@dpinsen yes those are my sentiments precisely.
@dpinsen you're missing my point. Outcome is right one, but reasoning for it is saddening.
@JayGeraghty I'm sorry. You're going to have to actually structure a sentence together. I don't speak Crypto absurdity.
@JayGeraghty what use is that information to me? I'm very happy for you that gt has your number. Well done.
@JayGeraghty if i was, i wouldn't tell you on twitter.
@dpinsen and not for the greater sin that Uber is and always was taking advantage of labour rates.
@dpinsen yes it's the right outcome. But it's annoying it's come about coz of ppl's want to reflect reactionary social media kudos pts
@dpinsen my point is that if you want to show solidarity to migrants you shouldn't empower a service that exploits their labour willfully
@shaneferro thanks very much! I only did two shifts. Pretty pathetic really. But hard enough!
@shaneferro Will shut up now. Have got it off my chest
@shaneferro Let's not forget they ultimately want to fire all the drivers anyway and replace them with self-driving cars.
@shaneferro yes. Especially if they're liberals. Sorry. But hypocrisy is hypocrisy. I feel v strongly about this. (hence video)
@shaneferro Fundamentally, Uber's biz model is OPEC-ian - involves subsidizing costs until competition wiped out & labour power wiped out
@shaneferro "oh but it's so convenient, and so cheap". Yes upstairs downstairs labour was also "so convenient & so cheap" for elite
@shaneferro I can't tell u how many blue in the face arguments i've had w/ ppl trying to explain y Uber is exploitative.
@callan_m it's crazy that it takes an immigration EO for ppl to figure this out.
@callan_m I just think ppl r such hypocrites sometimes. They're happy to condone exploitative corps until their own agenda changes
@_TechBanker that said, either way, I'm glad there's an uber boycott. About time. That's all.
@_TechBanker I'm happy there's an Uber boycott, but it should have been due to an obviously exploitative model not this boycott thing
@shaneferro my gripe is with ppl who make empty social media gestures 4 kudos pts but continue bad real-world behaviours regardless
@shaneferro that's generally my issue. It's an empty feel-good gesture - & ultimately hypocritical given willful exploitation blindness b4
@andrew_graham it's not that easy to transfer ratings history, and some have Uber specific lease agreements.
@shaneferro Well to be clear, it's not that easy to just switch. Drivers have ratings invested in Uber & sometimes leases
@callan_m problem is, if they did that, they would never make a profit in a million years.
@callan_m sadly, we are so deep into the flawed business model, that is now true. But they could admit they're employees & create payroll
@shaneferro that may be true. I don't know details of the communication. If they signaled "low rates" despite boycott that was dumb
@callan_m when it's a scab, it's someone who defies a picket in favour of big boss. In this case, they r self-employed
@callan_m I don't. These r private contractors. Many of whom have invested in ratings & contracts.
@czwalsh @shaneferro taxis are a super low margin business even in the medallion format https://t.co/ZmjUENW3lX
@czwalsh @shaneferro Because the cost of service is ridiculously expensive. Human labour IS expensive.
@Sociopathblog If Trump's EO made people realise Uber is an opportunistic migrant exploiting company there is a silver lining
@shaneferro Look, I deleted my Uber app over 6 mths ago. Not a fan of the company. But being outraged by drivers who choose to work is silly
@shaneferro but that's the problem with a service which has totally variable & discretionary charges in general!
@shaneferro but i think it's ridiculous that the trigger for the switch is their lack of respect for a boycott they can't afford to observe
@shaneferro I'd be very happy to see entire world switch to a service that doesn't undercut competition below breakeven costs
@Sociopathblog it's ridiculous.
@Sociopathblog That's my point tho. Uber's been exploiting migrants since getgo. But private contractors not supporting boycott flips ppl?
@callan_m those drivers wd have taken that decision probably coz can't afford not to take this work?
@callan_m I just think punishing Uber PRIVATE CONTRACTORS for not respecting a boycott is weird way 2 show solidarity
@shaneferro so my presumption (and it may be wrong) is that Uber drivers can't afford to not take biz.
@shaneferro pls do correct if i've misunderstood. But outrage is cause Uber didn't respect the boycott right?
@shaneferro that defies logic. If you're angry about a service not respecting a boycott, why would u not b angry about a competitor?
@_TechBanker or at least they used to have higher "cartel" style earnings (according to uber), hence prob can afford to strike.
@_TechBanker The migrants boycotting JFK were regular taxis to my knowledge. Higher earnings than Uber drivers!
@callan_m That's my point tho. If u want 2 show solidarity, don't empower a business model that is highly exploitative on an everyday basis!
@shaneferro we're perfectly happy paying them exploitative wages for the below cost services all other times.
@shaneferro sure. But i don't understand why depriving migrants of income they can't afford to lose is deemed solidarity.
Uber drivers (often immigrants) barely make minimum wage. But deleting the app & depriving them of income is a sign of migrant solidarity?

@johnb78 if you're an AV reader i wd hope you appreciate that my views tend to be nuanced coz I think absolutism on either side is unhelpful
@johnb78 but I'm now out of time. And bowing out not because "i can't face the opposition" because personal time is a thing
@johnb78 I hv endeavoured to respectfully defend my case ( esp. coz I see myself as a moderate who is Pigeonholed as both left or right)
@johnb78 it's because people jump on tweets and assume all sorts - out of context - that I think the medium is flawed for serious debate
@johnb78 and while I endeavour to be thorough and non contradictory I can lose track of multiple threads
@johnb78 I specifically state earlier that my argument does not apply to the U.K., which is a much more complex case
@johnb78 just because there are facts doesn't mean they're not biased by context or omission
@johnb78 no you are. I was always taking about the US. And PS that's the nature of all fact based narratives.
@johnb78 just to be clear https://t.co/DYCz3H3BUL
@johnb78 and I agree with you that there will be many justifiable exceptions which should be given a chance to sort their documents out
@johnb78 again, my point is simply about respect for the law. You need some sort of stick to at least get the thing sorted.
@johnb78 well shame Obama's policy worked so well there are still so many indeterminants left
@johnb78 I haven't pretended. It IS still a thing.
@johnb78 again, presumptions. I have stayed clear of political declarations. It's so typically lazy to just assume people's politics
@johnb78 doesn't change fact they should either be legalized or leave, and that everything else is an unfair contradiction
@johnb78 I admire your commitment to going off topic
@johnb78 a loophole closure enables that process.
@johnb78 again you're clutching at straws. If they're so compliant why aren't they should be fully legalized
@johnb78 again not when you strip out joy riding (cases when cars r often recovered).
@johnb78 @j0s3fk I think you're the one who lives in an idealized paradoxical world where tracking = security unless it's illegal migration
